source.title: The Self-Guided Cultural Journey Route through the Squamish and Lil'wat First Nations

photo.desc: From the base of Black Tusk, looking around and out down the Howe Sound

divs.text: One day Sk'ewk (Raven) was livid with Wexés (Frog).
Sk'ewk picked up Waxes and carried him high into the sky.
As Wexés flailed, he grasped at the clouds and tore a large hole in them.
Wexés protested, demanding to be returned to the ground. Sk'ewk granted his wish by dropping him from the sky.
Torrential rains followed, flooding the land. This disturbed in7inyaxa7en (Thunderbird), who was resting on what is now known as Black Tusk.
He opened his eyes and sent lightning across the skies. in7inyaxa7en then flapped his wings, wreaking havoc and destruction everywhere.
Wexés landed in the rising waters, nearly hitting Yéw'yews (Killer Whale). Yéw'yews thrashed his tail, sending tidal waves in all directions, decimating most of the remaining population.
This is the series of events that initiated the great flood, a story that spans may cultures.
